subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: In a vacuum, a satellite with a mass of 950 kg is being towed by a spaceship using a homogeneous rope that is 50 m long, with a linear density of 1 kg/m, at a uniform acceleration of 5 m/sÂ² in a straight line. Calculate the force exerted by the spaceship on the rope.
solution:
The generalized forces for generalized coordinates $x, s$ are

$$
Q_{x}=F_{0} \cos \Omega t, \quad Q_{s}=0
$$

After applying the normal coordinates $\xi, \eta$, the relationship for generalized forces is given by:

$$
\begin{pmatrix} Q_{\xi} \\ Q_{\eta} \end{pmatrix} =\left(\begin{array}{cc} \frac{1}{2} & -\frac{3}{2} \\ -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} & -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \end{array}\right) \begin{pmatrix} Q_{x} \\ Q_{s} \end{pmatrix}
$$

where the transformation matrix is $\boldsymbol{G}^{\boldsymbol{T}}$. Substituting $Q_{x}, Q_{s}$ gives

$$
Q_{\xi}=\frac{1}{2} F_{0} \cos \Omega t, \quad Q_{\eta}=-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} F_{0} \cos \Omega t
$$

The differential equations are:

$$
\begin{gathered}
2 m \ddot{\xi}+k \xi=\frac{1}{2} F_{0} \cos \Omega t \\
6 m \ddot{\eta}+k \eta=-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} F_{0} \cos \Omega t
\end{gathered}
$$

The particular solutions are:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\xi^{*}= & \frac{\frac{F_{0}}{4 m}}{\frac{k}{2 m}-\Omega^{2}} \cos \Omega t=\frac{F_{0} l}{2 m\left(3 g-2 l \Omega^{2}\right)} \cos \Omega t \\
\eta^{*}= & \frac{-\sqrt{3} F_{0}}{\frac{k}{6 m}-\Omega^{2}} \cos \Omega t=\frac{-\sqrt{3} F_{0} l}{6 m\left(g-2 l \Omega^{2}\right)} \cos \Omega t
\end{aligned}
$$

The general solutions are:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \xi=\frac{F_{0} l}{2 m\left(3 g-2 l \Omega^{2}\right)} \cos \Omega t+C_{1}^{\prime} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{3 g}{2 l}} t+\alpha_{1}\right) \\
& \eta=-\frac{\sqrt{3} F_{0} l}{6 m\left(g-2 l \Omega^{2}\right)} \cos \Omega t+C_{2}^{\prime} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{g}{2 l}} t+\alpha_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Further, we obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
x= & \frac{1}{2} \xi - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \eta = \left[\frac{F_{0} l}{4 m(3 g-2 l \Omega^{2})} + \frac{F_{0} l}{4 m(g-2 l \Omega^{2})}\right] \cos \Omega t \\
& + C_{1} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{3g}{2l}} t+\alpha_{1}\right) + C_{2} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{g}{2l}} t+\alpha_{2}\right) \\
\theta= & -\frac{3}{2 l} \xi - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2 l} \eta = \left[-\frac{3 F_{0}}{4 m(3g-2l\Omega^{2})} + \frac{F_{0}}{4m(g-2l\Omega^{2})}\right] \cos \Omega t 
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
-\frac{3}{l} C_{1} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{3g}{2l}} t+\alpha_{1}\right) + \frac{1}{l} C_{2} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{g}{2l}} t+\alpha_{2}\right)
$$

$$
<image 1>
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: In a vacuum, a satellite with a mass of 950 kg is being pulled by a spaceship using a homogenous rope that is 50 meters long with a linear density of 1 kg/m. The satellite is moving with a constant acceleration of 5 m/sÂ² in a straight line. Calculate the tension distribution in the rope.
solution:
The generalized forces for generalized coordinates $x, s$ are

$$
Q_{x}=F_{0} \cos \Omega t, \quad Q_{s}=0
$$

After applying the normal coordinates $\xi, \eta$, the relationship for generalized forces is given by:

$$
\begin{pmatrix} Q_{\xi} \\ Q_{\eta} \end{pmatrix} =\left(\begin{array}{cc} \frac{1}{2} & -\frac{3}{2} \\ -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} & -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \end{array}\right) \begin{pmatrix} Q_{x} \\ Q_{s} \end{pmatrix}
$$

where the transformation matrix is $\boldsymbol{G}^{\boldsymbol{T}}$. Substituting $Q_{x}, Q_{s}$ gives

$$
Q_{\xi}=\frac{1}{2} F_{0} \cos \Omega t, \quad Q_{\eta}=-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} F_{0} \cos \Omega t
$$

The differential equations are:

$$
\begin{gathered}
2 m \ddot{\xi}+k \xi=\frac{1}{2} F_{0} \cos \Omega t \\
6 m \ddot{\eta}+k \eta=-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} F_{0} \cos \Omega t
\end{gathered}
$$

The particular solutions are:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\xi^{*}= & \frac{\frac{F_{0}}{4 m}}{\frac{k}{2 m}-\Omega^{2}} \cos \Omega t=\frac{F_{0} l}{2 m\left(3 g-2 l \Omega^{2}\right)} \cos \Omega t \\
\eta^{*}= & \frac{-\sqrt{3} F_{0}}{\frac{k}{6 m}-\Omega^{2}} \cos \Omega t=\frac{-\sqrt{3} F_{0} l}{6 m\left(g-2 l \Omega^{2}\right)} \cos \Omega t
\end{aligned}
$$

The general solutions are:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \xi=\frac{F_{0} l}{2 m\left(3 g-2 l \Omega^{2}\right)} \cos \Omega t+C_{1}^{\prime} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{3 g}{2 l}} t+\alpha_{1}\right) \\
& \eta=-\frac{\sqrt{3} F_{0} l}{6 m\left(g-2 l \Omega^{2}\right)} \cos \Omega t+C_{2}^{\prime} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{g}{2 l}} t+\alpha_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Further, we obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
x= & \frac{1}{2} \xi - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \eta = \left[\frac{F_{0} l}{4 m(3 g-2 l \Omega^{2})} + \frac{F_{0} l}{4 m(g-2 l \Omega^{2})}\right] \cos \Omega t \\
& + C_{1} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{3g}{2l}} t+\alpha_{1}\right) + C_{2} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{g}{2l}} t+\alpha_{2}\right) \\
\theta= & -\frac{3}{2 l} \xi - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2 l} \eta = \left[-\frac{3 F_{0}}{4 m(3g-2l\Omega^{2})} + \frac{F_{0}}{4m(g-2l\Omega^{2})}\right] \cos \Omega t 
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
-\frac{3}{l} C_{1} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{3g}{2l}} t+\alpha_{1}\right) + \frac{1}{l} C_{2} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{g}{2l}} t+\alpha_{2}\right)
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A particle with mass $m$, under the influence of gravity, falls vertically from rest and is subject to a resistive force that can be described by the dissipation function $R=\frac{1}{2} \gamma \dot{x}^{2}$. Prove that the maximum velocity of the particle is $\frac{mg}{\gamma}$.
solution:
Take the $x$-axis vertically downward,

From

$$
\begin{aligned}
& T=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2}, \quad V=-mgx, \\
& L=T-V=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{x}^{2} + mgx, \\
& R=\frac{1}{2} \gamma \dot{x}^{2}, \quad Q=-\frac{\partial R}{\partial \dot{x}}=-\gamma \dot{x}, \\
& \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{x}}\right) - \frac{\partial L}{\partial x}=Q \\
& m \ddot{x} - mg = -\gamma \dot{x}
\end{aligned}
$$

When the maximum velocity is reached, $\ddot{x}=0$. Substituting into the above equation gives

$$
\dot{x}_{\max} = \frac{mg}{\gamma}
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A particle with mass $m$ moves on a smooth parabola in the vertical plane described by $z=\frac{1}{a} x^{2}$ (where $a$ is a constant, and the $z$-axis is vertically upwards). Write the Lagrangian function.
solution:
Using $x$ as the generalized coordinate,

$$
\begin{gathered}
T=\frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2}+\dot{z}^{2}\right)=\frac{1}{2} m\left(1+\frac{4 x^{2}}{a^{2}}\right) \dot{x}^{2}, \\
V=m g z=\frac{1}{a} m g x^{2}, \\
L=\frac{1}{2} m\left(1+\frac{4 x^{2}}{a^{2}}\right) \dot{x}^{2}-\frac{1}{a} m g x^{2}.
\end{gathered}
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A particle moving in a uniform gravitational field is described using spherical coordinates, with the vertical upward direction taken as the polar axis. Find the generalized force component of gravity in the \( \varphi \) direction.
solution:
Solution

Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
Q_{\varphi} & =0
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: Consider a homogeneous rod of length $l$ and mass $M$ moving in the vertical $xz$ plane. One end of the rod, $A$, is constrained to slide along the line $z = x \tan \alpha$ (where $\alpha$ is the angle of the line with respect to the horizontal $x$ axis). Using the generalized coordinates shown in Figure 7.59: $s$ and $\theta$. Under the condition of pure translation, determine the value of $\theta$.
solution:
In pure translation, $\dot{\theta}=0, \ddot{\theta}=0$. Substituting into the motion differential equations, we have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \ddot{s} - g \sin \alpha = 0 \\
& \ddot{s} \cos (\theta-\alpha) - g \sin \theta = 0
\end{aligned}
$$

Eliminating $\ddot{s}$ from the second equation using the first equation, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sin \alpha \cos (\theta-\alpha) - \sin \theta = 0 \\
& \sin \alpha(\cos \theta \cos \alpha + \sin \theta \sin \alpha) - \sin \theta = 0 \\
& \sin \alpha \cos \alpha \cos \theta - \sin \theta \left(1-\sin^{2} \alpha\right) = 0 \\
& \sin \alpha \cos \theta - \sin \theta \cos \alpha = 0 \\
& \sin (\alpha-\theta) = 0 \\
& \quad \theta = \alpha \text{ or } \pi + \alpha
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A solid sphere with mass $m$ and radius $r$ rolls on the inner surface of a fixed spherical shell with radius $R$. Assuming the condition for pure rolling exists: $(R - r) \dot{\theta} - r \dot{\varphi} = 0$, find the expression for $\dot{\varphi}$.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A solid sphere with mass $m$ and radius $r$ rolls on the inner surface of a fixed spherical shell with radius $R$. Use the Lagrangian equation to determine the period $T$ of small oscillations of the sphere near its equilibrium position.
solution:
From the Lagrangian equation

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right) - \frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta} = 0
$$

we obtain

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{7}{5} m (R - r)^{2} \ddot{\theta} + m g (R - r) \theta = 0 \\
\omega = \sqrt{\frac{5 g}{7 (R - r)}} \\
T = \frac{2 \pi}{\omega} = 2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{7 (R - r)}{5 g}}
\end{gathered}
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: Consider a homogeneous rod of length \( l \) and mass \( M \), moving within a vertical \( xz \) plane. One end, \( A \), of the rod is constrained to slide along the line \( z = x \tan \alpha \) (where \( \alpha \) is the angle of the line with respect to the horizontal \( x \)-axis). Utilize the generalized coordinates shown in Figure 7.59: \( s \) and \( \theta \). Compute the expressions for the kinetic energy \( T \) and the potential energy \( V \).
solution:
The kinetic energy is:

$$
T = \frac{1}{2} M\left(\dot{x}_{C}^{2} + \dot{z}_{C}^{2}\right) + \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{12} M l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2}
$$

Simplifying gives:

$$
T = \frac{1}{2} M \left[ \dot{s}^{2} + \frac{1}{3} l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} - l \dot{s} \dot{\theta} \cos (\theta-\alpha) \right]
$$

The potential energy is:

$$
V = -M g z_{C} = -M g \left( s \sin \alpha + \frac{l}{2} \cos \theta \right)
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: Given two types of vector potentials: \( \boldsymbol{A} = \frac{1}{2} r B_{0} \boldsymbol{e}_{\varphi} \) and \( \boldsymbol{A}^{\prime} = -B_{0} r \sin \varphi \left( \cos \varphi \, \boldsymbol{e}_{r} - \sin \varphi \, \boldsymbol{e}_{\varphi} \right) \). Prove that there exists a \( \Lambda \) such that \( \boldsymbol{A}^{\prime} = \boldsymbol{A} + \nabla \Lambda \), and determine this \( \Lambda \).
solution:
A \( \Lambda \) can be found such that \( \boldsymbol{A}^{\prime} = \boldsymbol{A} + \nabla \Lambda \). This \( \Lambda \) is:

\[
\Lambda = -\frac{1}{2} B_{0} r^{2} \sin \varphi \cos \varphi
\]

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: In a Cartesian coordinate system rotating with a constant angular velocity \(\omega\) about the \(z\)-axis relative to an inertial frame, a particle of mass \(m\) moves under the influence of a potential energy \(V(x, y, z)\). Using \(x, y, z\) as generalized coordinates, write the Lagrangian function for this particle.
solution:
The kinetic energy \(T\) is

\[
T = \frac{1}{2} m \left[(\dot{x} - \omega y)^2 + (\dot{y} + \omega x)^2 + \dot{z}^2\right] = \frac{1}{2} m \left( \dot{x}^2 + \dot{y}^2 + \dot{z}^2 \right) + \frac{1}{2} m \omega^2 (x^2 + y^2) + m \omega (x \dot{y} - y \dot{x})
\]

The Lagrangian function \(L\) is:

\[
L = T - V = \frac{1}{2} m \left( \dot{x}^2 + \dot{y}^2 + \dot{z}^2 \right) + \frac{1}{2} m \omega^2 (x^2 + y^2) + m \omega (x \dot{y} - y \dot{x}) - V(x, y, z)
\]
answers: \boxed{\frac{1}{2} m \left( \dot{x}^2 + \dot{y}^2 + \dot{z}^2 \right) + \frac{1}{2} m \omega^2 (x^2 + y^2) + m \omega (x \dot{y} - y \dot{x}) - V(x, y, z)}

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: For a particle of mass \( m \) under the force \( f = \frac{k}{x^{2}} \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{t}{\tau}} \), is its Hamiltonian a constant of motion?
solution: Since \(\frac{\partial H}{\partial t} \neq 0\), \( H \) is not a constant of motion.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A particle with mass $m$ moves in a plane using $r$ and $\sin \varphi$ as generalized coordinates. Find the kinetic energy of the particle.
solution:
Let $x = r \cos \varphi, \ y = r \sin \varphi$. Now using $r$ and $q = \sin \varphi$ as generalized coordinates,

$$
\begin{aligned}
x & = r \cos \varphi = r \sqrt{1-q^{2}} \\
y & = r \sin \varphi = r q \\
\dot{x} & = \dot{r} \sqrt{1-q^{2}} - \frac{r q \dot{q}}{\sqrt{1-q^{2}}} \\
\dot{y} & = \dot{r} q + r \dot{q} \\
T & = \frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2} + \dot{y}^{2}\right) = \frac{1}{2} m\left[\left(\dot{r} \sqrt{1-q^{2}} - \frac{r q \dot{q}}{\sqrt{1-q^{2}}}\right)^{2} + (\dot{r} q + r \dot{q})^{2}\right] \\
& = \frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2} + \frac{r^{2} \dot{q}^{2}}{1-q^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A particle with unit mass moves along the \( x \)-axis under the action of an external force \( F=-(x+t) \). It is located at \( x=0 \) at both \( t=0 \) and \( t=1 \). Determine the exact solution to this problem.
solution:
\[
\begin{gathered}
T=\frac{1}{2} \dot{x}^{2}, \quad V=-\frac{1}{2}(x+t)^{2} \\
L=\frac{1}{2} \dot{x}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}(x+t)^{2}
\end{gathered}
\]

Using Hamilton's principle or the Lagrange equation, the differential equation of motion is obtained as

\[
\ddot{x}=-(x+t)
\]

To find the exact solution, let \( y=x+t \), then \( x=y-t \), thus

\[
\begin{gathered}
\dot{x}=\dot{y}-1, \quad \ddot{x}=\ddot{y} \\
\ddot{y}=-y \\
y=c_{1} \sin \left(t+c_{2}\right) \\
x=c_{1} \sin \left(t+c_{2}\right)-t
\end{gathered}
\]

By using \( x=0 \) at \( t=0 \) and \( t=1 \), solve for \( c_{1} \) and \( c_{2} \), obtaining

\[
\begin{gathered}
c_{1}=\frac{1}{\sin 1}, \quad c_{2}=0 \\
x=\frac{\sin t}{\sin 1}-t
\end{gathered}
\]

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: In the $xy$ plane, any point can be represented using coordinates $c, x$, where $c$ satisfies $xy = c$. If gravity acts in the negative direction along the $y$-axis, determine the generalized force exerted by gravity on a particle of mass $m$.
solution:
When choosing $c, x$ as generalized coordinates,

$$
\delta W=-m g \delta y
$$

Since

$$
\begin{gathered}
y=\frac{c}{x}, \quad \delta y=\frac{1}{x} \delta c-\frac{1}{x^{2}} \delta x \\
\delta W=-m g\left(\frac{1}{x} \delta c-\frac{1}{x^{2}} \delta x\right) \\
Q_{c}=-\frac{m g}{x}, \quad Q_{x}=\frac{m g c}{x^{2}}
\end{gathered}
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A particle with mass $m$ is moving in one dimension under the influence of a force $f=\frac{k}{x^{2}} \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{t}{\tau}}$ (where $k$ and $\tau$ are positive constants). Write down its Hamiltonian function.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A particle with mass $m$ moves on a smooth plane under the influence of an attractive force from a fixed point $P$ on the plane. The magnitude of the force is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from point $P$, with a proportionality constant of $k$. Write the Lagrangian function of this particle in polar coordinates.
solution:
Take point $P$ as the origin of the polar coordinate system,

$$
\boldsymbol{F} = -\frac{k}{r^2} \hat{\boldsymbol{r}}
$$

Assume the potential energy at infinity is zero,

$$
\begin{aligned}
V(r) &= -\int_{\infty}^{r} \boldsymbol{F} \cdot \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{r} = \int_{r}^{\infty}\left(-\frac{k}{r^2}\right) \mathrm{d}r = -\frac{k}{r}, \\
T &= \frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^2 + r^2 \dot{\varphi}^2\right), \\
L &= T - V = \frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^2 + r^2 \dot{\varphi}^2\right) + \frac{k}{r}.
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A particle with mass $m$ moves in one dimension under the influence of a force $f = \frac{k}{x^{2}} \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{t}{\tau}}$ (where both $k$ and $\tau$ are positive constants). Write down its Lagrangian function.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem:
A particle with mass \(m\) moves on the surface of a sphere with radius \(R\), without being subjected to any external forces.  
How many generalized coordinates are required for this problem?
solution: Since the particle is constrained to move on a spherical surface, two generalized coordinates are needed to describe its motion.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A particle with unit mass moves along the \( x \)-axis under the external force \( F=-(x+t) \). It is located at \( x=0 \) at both \( t=0 \) and \( t=1 \). Use the Ritz method to find an approximate solution for this problem, calculating only for \( n=0 \).
solution:
Below, we use the Ritz method to find the approximate solution:

\[
\int L \mathrm{~d} t=\int\left[\frac{1}{2} \dot{x}^{2}-\frac{1}{2}(x+t)^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} t
\]

Assume:

\[
\begin{gathered}
x(t)=\alpha_{0} t(1-t) \\
\dot{x}=\alpha_{0}-2 \alpha_{0} t \\
\phi\left(\alpha_{0}\right)=\int_{0}^{1}\left[\frac{1}{2}\left(\alpha_{0}-2 \alpha_{0} t\right)^{2}-\frac{1}{2}\left(\alpha_{0} t-\alpha_{0} t^{2}+t\right)^{2}\right] \mathrm{d} t
\end{gathered}
\]

Upon calculation, we get:

\[
\phi\left(\alpha_{0}\right)=\frac{3}{20} \alpha_{0}^{2}-\frac{1}{12} \alpha_{0}-\frac{1}{6}
\]

Determine the value of \( \alpha_{0} \) by finding the extremum of \( \phi\left(\alpha_{0}\right) \),

The approximate solution is:

\[
\begin{gathered}
\frac{d \phi}{d \alpha_{0}}=\frac{3}{10} \alpha_{0}-\frac{1}{12}=0 \\
\alpha_{0}=\frac{5}{18} \\
x=\frac{5}{18}t(1-t)
\end{gathered}
\]

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A particle moves in a uniform gravitational field, described using spherical coordinates, with the vertically upward direction as the polar axis. Find the component of the generalized force of gravity in the \( r \) direction.
solution:
Solution

So

$$
\begin{aligned}
\delta W & =-m g \delta z \\
z & =r \cos \theta \\
\delta z & =\cos \theta \, \delta r - r \sin \theta \, \delta \theta \\
\delta W & =-m g \cos \theta \, \delta r + m g r \sin \theta \, \delta \theta \\
Q_{r} & =-m g \cos \theta \\
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem:
Determine the dissipation function \( R \) of a ring with radius \( r \), given that the mass element of the ring is located in the region \(\alpha \sim \alpha+\mathrm{d}\alpha\). The frictional force acting on each element of the ring is described by the following expression:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -f \frac{\left[\dot{x}-r \dot{\varphi} \sin (\varphi+\alpha)\right] i+\left[\dot{y}+r \dot{\varphi} \cos (\varphi+\alpha)\right] j}{\left\{\left[\dot{x}-r \dot{\varphi} \sin (\varphi+\alpha)\right]^{2}+\left[\dot{y}+r \dot{\varphi} \cos (\varphi+\alpha)\right]^{2}\right\}^{1 / 2}} r \mathrm{~d} \alpha \\
& \dot{x}^{\prime}=\dot{x}-r \dot{\varphi} \sin (\varphi+\alpha), \\
& \dot{y}^{\prime}=\dot{y}+r \dot{\varphi} \cos (\varphi+\alpha).
\end{aligned}
$$
solution:
$$
\begin{aligned}
R= & \int_{0}^{2 \pi}\left(f \frac{\left[\dot{x}-r \dot{\varphi} \sin (\varphi+\alpha)\right] \mathrm{d}[\dot{x}-r \dot{\varphi} \sin (\varphi+\alpha)]}{\left\{\left[\dot{x}-r \dot{\varphi} \sin (\varphi+\alpha)\right]^{2}+\left[\dot{y}+r \dot{\varphi} \cos (\varphi+\alpha)\right]^{2}\right\}^{1 / 2}}\right. \\
& \left.+f \frac{\left[\dot{y}+r \dot{\varphi} \cos (\varphi+\alpha)\right] \mathrm{d}[\dot{y}+r \dot{\varphi} \cos (\varphi+\alpha)]}{\left\{\left[\dot{x}-r \dot{\varphi} \sin (\varphi+\alpha)\right]^{2}+\left[\dot{y}+r \dot{\varphi} \cos (\varphi+\alpha)\right]^{2}\right\}^{1 / 2}}\right) r \mathrm{~d} \alpha \\
= & r f \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \frac{\frac{1}{2} \mathrm{d}\left\{\left[\dot{x}-r \dot{\varphi} \sin (\varphi+\alpha)\right]^{2}+\left[\dot{y}+r \dot{\varphi} \cos (\varphi+\alpha)\right]^{2}\right\}}{\left\{\left[\dot{x}-r \dot{\varphi} \sin (\varphi+\alpha)\right]^{2}+\left[\dot{y}+r \dot{\varphi} \cos (\varphi+\alpha)\right]^{2}\right\}^{1 / 2}} \mathrm{~d} \alpha \\
= & r f \int_{0}^{2 \pi}\left\{\left[\dot{x}-r \dot{\varphi} \sin (\varphi+\alpha)\right]^{2}+\left[\dot{y}+r \dot{\varphi} \cos (\varphi+\alpha)\right]^{2}\right\}^{1 / 2} \mathrm{~d} \alpha
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem:
Given a one-dimensional Lagrangian function

$$
L = e^{\gamma t} \left(\frac{1}{2} m \dot{q}^{2} - \frac{1}{2} k q^{2}\right)
$$

where $\gamma, m, k$ are all positive constants. If we use the generalized coordinate $s$, with the transformation relation to the original generalized coordinate $q$ given by $s = e^{\frac{1}{2} \gamma t} q$, rewrite the Lagrangian function, the Lagrange equation, and discuss whether any constants of motion can be directly written. Also, explain the relationship between the two solutions.
solution:
If we use the generalized coordinate $s$, where $s = e^{\frac{1}{2} \gamma t} q$, then

\begin{align*}
& q = e^{-\frac{1}{2} \gamma t} s, \quad \dot{q} = e^{-\frac{1}{2} \gamma t} \dot{s} - \frac{1}{2} \gamma e^{-\frac{1}{2} \gamma t} s, \\
& L = e^{\gamma t} \left[\frac{1}{2} m \left(e^{-\frac{1}{2} \gamma t} \dot{s} - \frac{1}{2} \gamma e^{-\frac{1}{2} \gamma t} s\right)^{2} - \frac{1}{2} k \left(e^{-\frac{1}{2} \gamma t} s\right)^{2}\right] \\
& = \frac{1}{2} m \left(\dot{s} - \frac{1}{2} \gamma s\right)^{2} - \frac{1}{2} k s^{2} \\
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{s}} = m \left(\dot{s} - \frac{1}{2} \gamma s\right), \quad \frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} t} \left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{s}}\right) = m \left(\ddot{s} - \frac{1}{2} \gamma \dot{s}\right) \\
& \frac{\partial L}{\partial s} = -\frac{1}{2} m \gamma \left(\dot{s} - \frac{1}{2} \gamma s\right) - k s = -\frac{1}{2} m \gamma \dot{s} - \left(k - \frac{1}{4} m \gamma^{2}\right) s \\
& m \left(\ddot{s} - \frac{1}{2} \gamma \dot{s}\right) + \frac{1}{2} m \gamma \dot{s} + \left(k - \frac{1}{4} m \gamma^{2}\right) s = 0 \\
& \ddot{s} + \left(\frac{k}{m} - \frac{\gamma^{2}}{4}\right) s = 0 \tag{1}
\end{align*}

Since $\frac{\partial L}{\partial t} = 0$, we can directly write a constant of motion:

$$
\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{s}} \dot{s} - L = \text{constant}
$$

i.e.,

$$
\frac{1}{2} m \dot{s}^{2} + \frac{1}{2} m \left(\frac{k}{m} - \frac{\gamma^{2}}{4}\right) s^{2} = \text{constant}
$$

From the differential equation of motion (1), it is evident that if $\frac{k}{m} > \frac{\gamma^{2}}{4}$, i.e., $\frac{\gamma}{2} < \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}$, the particle exhibits simple harmonic motion using coordinate $s$; using coordinate $q$, the particle exhibits underdamped motion.

If $\frac{k}{m} < \frac{\gamma^{2}}{4}$, i.e., $\frac{\gamma}{2} > \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}$, regardless of whether using coordinate $s$ or $q$, the particle's motion is overdamped.

If $\frac{k}{m} = \frac{\gamma^{2}}{4}$, i.e., $\frac{\gamma}{2} = \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}$, regardless of whether using coordinate $s$ or $q$, the particle's motion is critically damped.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A particle with mass \(m\) moves along a straight line in a time-dependent potential field, given by \(V = m A x t^{2}\), where \(A\) is a constant. Use the Lagrange-Hamilton method to find the general solution for the motion of this particle. Calculate the Lagrangian equation and the corresponding momentum.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A particle is moving in a uniform gravitational field, and the motion of the particle is described using spherical coordinates, with the vertical upward direction as the polar axis. Find the generalized force component of gravity in the \( \theta \) direction.
solution:
Solution

Therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
\delta W & =-m g \delta z \\
z & =r \cos \theta \\
\delta z & =\cos \theta \, \delta r - r \sin \theta \, \delta \theta \\
\delta W & =-m g \cos \theta \, \delta r + m g r \sin \theta \, \delta \theta \\
Q_{\theta} & =m g r \sin \theta \\
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem:
A simple classical model of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ consists of a linear structure formed by three particles, with interatomic forces replaced by spring forces. The natural length of the two springs is $l$, and the spring constant is $k$. Movement is allowed only along the line. The mass of $\mathrm{C}^{4+}$ is $M$, and the mass of $\mathrm{O}^{2-}$ is $m$.  
(1) How many vibrational degrees of freedom does this system have?
solution: (1) The system has three degrees of freedom, but only two vibrational degrees of freedom.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: Using polar coordinates \( (r, \varphi) \), write the Hamiltonian function for a particle of unit mass moving in a generalized potential field \(U=\frac{1+\dot{r}^{2}}{r}\).
solution:
$$
\begin{gathered}
T = \frac{1}{2}\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}\right), \\
U = \frac{1+\dot{r}^{2}}{r}, \\
L = T - U = \frac{1}{2}\left(\dot{r}^{2}+r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2}\right) - \frac{1+\dot{r}^{2}}{r}, \\
p_{r} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}} = \dot{r} - \frac{2 \dot{r}}{r}, \quad \dot{r} = \frac{r}{r-2} p_{r}, \\
p_{\varphi} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\varphi}} = r^{2} \dot{\varphi}, \quad \dot{\varphi} = \frac{1}{r^{2}} p_{\varphi}, \\
H = p_{r} \dot{r} + p_{\varphi} \dot{\varphi} - L = \frac{r}{2(r-2)} p_{r}^{2} + \frac{1}{2 r^{2}} p_{\varphi}^{2} + \frac{1}{r}, \\
\end{gathered}
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: Two particles with masses $m_1$ and $m_2$ are connected by a light spring with a spring constant $k$, resting on a smooth horizontal surface. Is it possible to apply an impulse to $m_1$ so that the system transitions from rest to non-oscillatory rotation?
solution:
It is not possible, because in order to apply an impulse to $m_1$ that transitions the system from rest to non-oscillatory rotation, the impulse must be perpendicular to the spring. If the impulse is $I$, the velocity of $m_1$ becomes $\frac{I}{m_1}$, while the velocity of $m_2$ remains zero. Assuming that afterward, $m_1$ rotates around $m_2$ without oscillation, and taking the reference frame of $m_2$ as moving linearly, considering it as a two-body problem, $m_1$'s mass is replaced with an effective mass. The centripetal force needed for this rotation is

$$
\frac{m_1 m_2}{m_1 + m_2}\left(\frac{I}{m_1}\right)^2,
$$

where $l$ is the natural length of the spring, but the spring remains in its original length state and exerts no force on $m_1$, thus unable to provide the required centripetal force. Therefore, it is impossible to apply an impulse to $m_1$ that transitions the system from rest to non-oscillatory rotation.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A pendulum is suspended from a support that is driven horizontally as a function of time, as shown in Figure 10.55. Given the motion of the support \( x_{\mathrm{s}}(t) \), write the differential equation of motion that the angle \(\theta\) between the pendulum string and the vertical satisfies.
solution:
Taking the support as the reference frame,

\[
L = \frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \dot{\theta}^{2} - m g l(1 - \cos \theta)
\]

The inertial force acting to the right on the pendulum bob is

\[
\begin{aligned}
&-m \ddot{x}_{\mathrm{s}}(t) \\
&\delta W = -m \ddot{x}_{\mathrm{s}}(t) \cos \theta \cdot l \delta \theta
\end{aligned}
\]

The generalized force of the inertial force is

\[
Q = -m l \ddot{x}_{\mathrm{s}}(t) \cos \theta
\]

According to \(\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} t}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\theta}}\right) - \frac{\partial L}{\partial \theta} = Q\), the differential equation of motion is

\[
l \ddot{\theta} + g \sin \theta = -\ddot{x}_{\mathrm{s}}(t) \cos \theta
\]

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A solid sphere with a mass of $m$ and a radius of $r$ rolls inside the surface of a fixed spherical shell of radius $R$. Based on the given expression for $\dot{\varphi}$, derive the expressions for the kinetic energy $T$ and the potential energy $V$ of the sphere during small oscillations.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: Find the canonical transformation generated by the generating function \( S_{3}(\boldsymbol{q}, \boldsymbol{P}, t) = \sum_{i=1}^{s} q_{i} P_{i} \).
solution:
\[
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
p_{i}=\frac{\partial S_{3}}{\partial q_{i}}=P_{i} \\
Q_{i}=\frac{\partial S_{3}}{\partial P_{i}}=q_{i}
\end{array} \quad(i=1,2, \cdots, s)\right.
\]

is an identity transformation.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A particle with mass $m$ undergoes one-dimensional motion under the potential energy $V(x) = F|x|$ (where $F$ is a positive constant). Use the action variable to calculate $J = \oint p \, \mathrm{d}x$ and solve for $E$ as a function of $J$.
solution:
$$
\begin{aligned}
J &= \oint p \, \mathrm{d}x = 2 \int_{-\frac{E}{F}}^{\frac{E}{F}} \sqrt{2m(E - V)} \, \mathrm{d} x \\
&= 2 \left[ \int_{-\frac{E}{F}}^{0} \sqrt{2m(E + Fx)} \, \mathrm{d}x + \int_{0}^{\frac{E}{F}} \sqrt{2m(E - Fx)} \, \mathrm{d}x \right] \\
&= \frac{8 \sqrt{2m}}{3F} E^{3/2} \\
E &= \left( \frac{3FJ}{8 \sqrt{2m}} \right)^{2/3} \\
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: Write the Hamiltonian function for a particle of mass \( m \) moving in a potential field \( V(x, y, z) \) using cylindrical coordinates.
solution:
In cylindrical coordinates \( r, \varphi, z \),

\[
\begin{gathered}
x = r \cos \varphi, \quad y = r \sin \varphi, \\
\dot{x} = \dot{r} \cos \varphi - r \dot{\varphi} \sin \varphi, \\
\dot{y} = \dot{r} \sin \varphi + r \dot{\varphi} \cos \varphi, \\
T = \frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{x}^{2} + \dot{y}^{2} + \dot{z}^{2}\right) = \frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2} + r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} + \dot{z}^{2}\right), \\
L = \frac{1}{2} m\left(\dot{r}^{2} + r^{2} \dot{\varphi}^{2} + \dot{z}^{2}\right) - V(r \cos \varphi, r \sin \varphi, z), \\
p_{r} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{r}} = m \dot{r}, \quad p_{\varphi} = \frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{\varphi}} = m r^{2} \dot{\varphi}, \quad p_{z} = m \dot{z}, \\
H = p_{r} \dot{r} + p_{\varphi} \dot{\varphi} + p_{z} \dot{z} - L, \\
= \frac{p_{r}^{2}}{2 m} + \frac{p_{\varphi}^{2}}{2 m r^{2}} + \frac{p_{z}^{2}}{2 m} + V(r \cos \varphi, r \sin \varphi, z).
\end{gathered}
\]
answers: \boxed{\frac{p_{r}^{2}}{2 m} + \frac{p_{\varphi}^{2}}{2 m r^{2}} + \frac{p_{z}^{2}}{2 m} + V(r \cos \varphi, r \sin \varphi, z)}

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A particle with mass $m$ is suspended from one end of a massless, inextensible string. The string passes through a small hole on a table and is pulled upwards at a constant rate $\alpha$. Initially, the string's length is $l_0$, and the particle moves in a vertical plane. The Hamiltonian of the system is given by $H = \frac{p_{\theta}^{2}}{2m\left(l_0 - \alpha t\right)^{2}} - \frac{1}{2} m \alpha^{2} - mg\left(l_0 - \alpha t\right) \cos \theta$. Is this Hamiltonian the total energy? Is it a constant of motion?
solution:
Since $T = T_{2} + T_{1} + T_{0}$ (where $T_{2}$, $T_{1}$, $T_{0}$ are respectively quadratic, linear, and constant functions of the generalized velocities),

$$
H = T_{2} - T_{0} + V \neq T + V
$$

Therefore, $H$ is not the total energy. Because $\frac{\partial H}{\partial t} \neq 0$, $H$ is also not a constant of motion.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: Find the canonical transformation generated by the generating function \( S_{1}(\boldsymbol{q}, \boldsymbol{Q}, t)=\sum_{i=1}^{s} q_{i} Q_{i} \).
solution:
From \(\sum_{i=1}^{s} p_{i} \, \mathrm{d} q_{i}-\sum_{i=1}^{s} P_{i} \, \mathrm{d} Q_{i}=\mathrm{d} S_{1}(\boldsymbol{q}, \boldsymbol{Q})\) we obtain

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
p_{i}=\frac{\partial S_{1}}{\partial q_{i}}=Q_{i} \\
P_{i}=-\frac{\partial S_{1}}{\partial Q_{i}}=-q_{i}
\end{array} \quad (i=1,2, \cdots, s)\right.
$$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem:
A particle with mass \( m \) moves under the influence of gravity on a smooth surface described by the equation

\[ z = x^{2} + y^{2} - x y \]

where the \( z \) axis points vertically upward. Determine the normal frequencies of small oscillations of the particle around the stable equilibrium position.
solution:
At the equilibrium position, \(\dot{x} = 0, \dot{y} = 0, \ddot{x} = 0, \ddot{y} = 0\). From the differential equations of motion or by \(\frac{\partial V}{\partial x} = 0, \frac{\partial V}{\partial y} = 0\), the equations satisfied at the equilibrium position are

\[  
\begin{aligned}  
& -2gx + gy = 0 \\  
& -2gy + gx = 0  
\end{aligned}  
\]  

Thus, it is evident that \( x = 0, y = 0 \) is the equilibrium position.

Near the equilibrium position, considering only second-order small quantities, the Lagrangian function can be approximated as

\[ L \approx \frac{1}{2}m(\dot{x}^{2} + \dot{y}^{2}) - mg(x^{2} + y^{2} - xy) \]

Using \(\frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial \dot{q}_{i}}\right) - \frac{\partial L}{\partial q_{i}} = 0\) or by approximating the differential equations of motion to consider only first-order small quantities, the differential equations of motion near the equilibrium position can be derived as

Let

\[  
\begin{aligned}  
& \ddot{x} = -2gx + gy \\  
& \ddot{y} = -2gy + gx \\  
& x = u_{1} \cos (\omega t + \alpha) \\  
& y = u_{2} \cos (\omega t + \alpha)  
\end{aligned}  
\]

Substituting these into the differential equations of motion, we get

\[  
\begin{pmatrix}  
2g - \omega^{2} & -g \\  
-g & 2g - \omega^{2}  
\end{pmatrix}  
\binom{u_{1}}{u_{2}} = 0  
\]  

The characteristic equation is

Solving yields

\[  
\begin{gathered}  
\left|\begin{array}{cc}  
2g - \omega^{2} & -g \\  
-g & 2g - \omega^{2}  
\end{array}\right| = 0 \\  
\omega^{4} - 4g\omega^{2} + 3g^{2} = 0  
\end{gathered}  
\]  

\(\omega_{1} = \sqrt{g}, \quad \omega_{2} = \sqrt{3g}\)

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: Use the canonical transformation generated by the generating function \( S_{1} = Q_{1}^{1/2} q_{1} - \frac{2}{3}(Q_{2} - q_{2})^{3/2} - (Q_{1} + Q_{2}) t \) to find the expressions for \( P_{1} \) and \( P_{2} \) in the system where the Hamiltonian is \( H = p_{1}^{2} + p_{2}^{2} + q_{2} \).
solution:
The canonical transformation is generated by the generating function
\[ 
S_{1} = Q_{1}^{1/2} q_{1} - \frac{2}{3}(Q_{2} - q_{2})^{3/2} - (Q_{1} + Q_{2}) t.
\]
The expressions are given by:
\[
\begin{aligned}
& P_{1} = -\frac{\partial S_{1}}{\partial Q_{1}} = \frac{1}{2} Q_{1}^{-1/2} q_{1} + t, \\
& P_{2} = -\frac{\partial S_{1}}{\partial Q_{2}} = \left(Q_{2} - q_{2}\right)^{1/2} + t.
\end{aligned}
\]

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: Find a curve in the \(xy\) plane that passes through two fixed points, such that its moment of inertia around the \(z\) axis is minimized. Write out the differential equation that this curve must satisfy using polar coordinates in the plane.
solution:
The curve's infinitesimal arc length is given by:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathrm{d} s=\sqrt{(\mathrm{d} r)^{2}+(r \mathrm{~d} \varphi)^{2}}=\sqrt{1+r^{2} \left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)^2} \mathrm{~d} r, \\
\phi=\frac{\mathrm{d} \varphi}{\mathrm{~d} r}
\end{gathered}
$$

Assuming a line density of \(\eta\), the moment of inertia of the infinitesimal arc length around the \(z\) axis is:

$$
\mathrm{d} I=\eta r^{2} \mathrm{~d} s=\eta r^{2} \sqrt{1+r^{2} \left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)^2} \mathrm{~d} r
$$

Thus, the moment of inertia of the curve around the \(z\) axis is:

$$
I=\int_{r_{0}}^{r_{1}} \eta r^{2} \sqrt{1+r^{2} \left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)^2} \mathrm{~d} r
$$

To minimize \(I\),

$$
\begin{gathered}
\delta I=\delta \int_{r_{0}}^{r_{1}} \eta r^{2} \sqrt{1+r^{2} \phi^{2}} \mathrm{~d} r=0 \\
F=r^{2} \sqrt{1+r^{2} \left(\varphi^{\prime}\right)^2}
\end{gathered}
$$

Assume

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} t}\left(\frac{\partial F}{\partial \varphi^{\prime}}\right)-\frac{\partial F}{\partial \varphi}=0
$$

Given \(\frac{\partial F}{\partial \varphi}=0\), we have \(\frac{\partial F}{\partial \varphi^{\prime}}=C\) (where \(C\) is a constant), leading to:

$$
\begin{aligned}
r^{2} \frac{2 r^{2} \phi^{\prime}}{2 \sqrt{1+r^{2} \phi^{2}}} & =C \\
\frac{r^{4}}{\sqrt{1+r^{2} \phi^{2}}} \phi^{\prime} & =C
\end{aligned}
$$

This is the required differential equation. Solving this equation yields a solution with an integration constant, and two integration constants are determined by the two fixed points the curve passes through.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A spherical pendulum consists of a particle with mass \(m\), suspended from a fixed point with a lightweight, non-stretchable string of length \(l\). The particle is constrained to move on the surface of a sphere. If the angle \(\theta_{0}\) between the string and the vertical remains constant, what is the angular velocity of the particle in this circular motion?
solution:
Let the angular velocity of this circular motion be \(\omega\). Consider a reference frame rotating with an angular velocity \(\omega\) around the vertical axis. At \(\theta = \theta_{0}\), the particle is in equilibrium. Using the principle of virtual work,

\[
V = -m g l \cos \theta - \frac{1}{2} m l^{2} \omega^{2} \sin^{2} \theta
\]

At \(\theta = \theta_{0}\), \(\frac{\partial V}{\partial \theta} = 0\), which leads to

\[
\begin{gathered}
m g l \sin \theta_{0} - m l^{2} \omega^{2} \sin \theta_{0} \cos \theta_{0} = 0 \\
\omega = \sqrt{\frac{g}{l \cos \theta_{0}}}
\end{gathered}
\]

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: A particle with mass $m$ in a uniform gravitational field is constrained to move on the surface of a sphere. The radius of the sphere $r$ changes with time, given by $r=r(t)$. With the center of the sphere as the origin and the vertical axis as the polar axis, using spherical coordinates $\theta, \varphi$ as generalized coordinates, determine whether the Hamiltonian function is the total energy.
solution: Since $T$ contains $T_{0}\left(T_{0}=\frac{1}{2} m \dot{r}^{2}\right.$, which is a known function of $t$), $H=T_{2}-T_{0}+V \neq T+V$, the Hamiltonian function is not the total energy.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem:
Consider a particle of mass $m$ moving in a two-dimensional potential field

$$
V(x, y) = -\frac{1}{2} k x^2 + \frac{1}{2} \lambda_{0} x^2 y^2 + \frac{1}{4} \lambda_{1} x^4
$$

where $(k, \lambda_{0}, \lambda_{1} > 0)$. Determine the normal frequencies of small oscillations around the equilibrium position, where the equilibrium condition is provided by $(x_0, y_0)$.
solution:
For small oscillations near the stable equilibrium positions $(\sqrt{\frac{k}{\lambda_{1}}}, 0)$ or $(-\sqrt{\frac{k}{\lambda_{1}}}, 0)$, the Lagrange equations are identical,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& m \ddot{x}^{\prime} + 2 k x^{\prime} = 0 \\
& m \ddot{y}^{\prime} + \frac{k \lambda_{0}}{\lambda_{1}} y^{\prime} = 0
\end{aligned}
$$

There are two normal frequencies: $\omega_{1} = \sqrt{\frac{2 k}{m}}$ for oscillations along the $x$-direction, and $\omega_{2} = \sqrt{\frac{k \lambda_{0}}{\lambda_{1}}}$ for oscillations along the $y$-direction. In other directions, the motion is a combination of simple harmonic motion with angular frequency $\omega_{1}$ in the $x$ direction and angular frequency $\omega_{2}$ in the $y$ direction.

For small oscillations near the third group of stable equilibrium positions $(0, y_{30})$,

$$
m \ddot{x} + \left(-k + \lambda_{0} y_{30}^{2}\right) x = 0
$$

there is one normal frequency: $\omega = \sqrt{\frac{-k + \lambda_{0} y_{30}^{2}}{m}}$, where $y_{30} > \sqrt{\frac{k}{\lambda_{0}}}$ or $y_{30} < -\sqrt{\frac{k}{\lambda_{0}}}$. However, these small oscillations are limited to the direction parallel to the $x$-axis, and thus, strictly speaking, these points cannot be considered stable equilibrium positions.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: The Lagrangian function for a particle of mass \(m\) moving in one dimension is given by \(L=\frac{1}{2} m e^{\gamma t}(\dot{x}^{2}-\omega^{2} x^{2})\), where \(m\), \(\gamma\), and \(\omega\) are positive real numbers. Is the Hamiltonian function a constant of motion? Is the mechanical energy conserved?
solution: \(\frac{\partial H}{\partial t} \neq 0\), so \(H\) is not a constant of motion, and the mechanical energy is not conserved. The elastic force is a conservative force, allowing the introduction of potential energy, but the resistance is a non-conservative force and does negative work overall, resulting in constantly decreasing mechanical energy.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem:
If two known functions $\varphi(\boldsymbol{q}, \boldsymbol{p}, t)$ and $\psi(\boldsymbol{q}, \boldsymbol{p}, t)$ satisfy the following identity:
$$
\varphi\left\{\frac{\partial \varphi}{\partial t}+[\varphi, H]\right\} \equiv \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial t}+[\psi, H]
$$
where $H$ is the Hamiltonian function, and both $[\varphi, H]$ and $[\psi, H]$ represent Poisson brackets, find a constant of motion for this canonical equation.
solution:
$$
\begin{gathered}
\varphi\left\{\frac{\partial \varphi}{\partial t}+[\varphi, H]\right\} \equiv \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial t}+[\psi, H] \\
\varphi\left\{\frac{\partial \varphi}{\partial t}+[\varphi, H]\right\}=\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\frac{1}{2} \varphi^{2}\right)+\left[\frac{1}{2} \varphi^{2}, H\right] \equiv \frac{\partial \psi}{\partial t}+[\psi, H] \\
\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\frac{1}{2} \varphi^{2}-\psi\right)+\left[\frac{1}{2} \varphi^{2}-\psi, H\right]=0
\end{gathered}
$$

Therefore, $\frac{1}{2} \varphi^{2}-\psi$ is a constant of motion.

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem:
Identify the first integral of motion for an isotropic three-dimensional harmonic oscillator. The Lagrangian function of the oscillator is given as

$$ L = \frac{1}{2} m(\dot{x}^2 + \dot{y}^2 + \dot{z}^2) - \frac{1}{2} k(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) $$
solution:
The Hamiltonian function is

$$ H = \frac{1}{2m}(p_x^2 + p_y^2 + p_z^2) + \frac{1}{2} k(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) $$

Since $\frac{\partial H}{\partial t} = 0$, $H$ is a conserved quantity, which leads to the integral of motion

$$ F_1 = H = \frac{1}{2m}(p_x^2 + p_y^2 + p_z^2) + \frac{1}{2} k(x^2 + y^2 + z^2) = C_1 $$

subject: Theoretical Mechanics
problem: Given a circle with radius \( r \) that is stationary in the inertial frame \( S^{\prime} \), and the center of the circle at position \( (x', y', z') = (0, 0, 0) \) in the \( S^{\prime} \) frame. The circle is moving with velocity \( v \) along the \( x \)-axis relative to the observerâs frame \( S \). Find the area of the circle as measured by the observer in the \( S \) frame.
solution:
The generalized forces for generalized coordinates $x, s$ are

$$
Q_{x}=F_{0} \cos \Omega t, \quad Q_{s}=0
$$

After applying the normal coordinates $\xi, \eta$, the relationship for generalized forces is given by:

$$
\begin{pmatrix} Q_{\xi} \\ Q_{\eta} \end{pmatrix} =\left(\begin{array}{cc} \frac{1}{2} & -\frac{3}{2} \\ -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} & -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \end{array}\right) \begin{pmatrix} Q_{x} \\ Q_{s} \end{pmatrix}
$$

where the transformation matrix is $\boldsymbol{G}^{\boldsymbol{T}}$. Substituting $Q_{x}, Q_{s}$ gives

$$
Q_{\xi}=\frac{1}{2} F_{0} \cos \Omega t, \quad Q_{\eta}=-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} F_{0} \cos \Omega t
$$

The differential equations are:

$$
\begin{gathered}
2 m \ddot{\xi}+k \xi=\frac{1}{2} F_{0} \cos \Omega t \\
6 m \ddot{\eta}+k \eta=-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} F_{0} \cos \Omega t
\end{gathered}
$$

The particular solutions are:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\xi^{*}= & \frac{\frac{F_{0}}{4 m}}{\frac{k}{2 m}-\Omega^{2}} \cos \Omega t=\frac{F_{0} l}{2 m\left(3 g-2 l \Omega^{2}\right)} \cos \Omega t \\
\eta^{*}= & \frac{-\sqrt{3} F_{0}}{\frac{k}{6 m}-\Omega^{2}} \cos \Omega t=\frac{-\sqrt{3} F_{0} l}{6 m\left(g-2 l \Omega^{2}\right)} \cos \Omega t
\end{aligned}
$$

The general solutions are:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \xi=\frac{F_{0} l}{2 m\left(3 g-2 l \Omega^{2}\right)} \cos \Omega t+C_{1}^{\prime} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{3 g}{2 l}} t+\alpha_{1}\right) \\
& \eta=-\frac{\sqrt{3} F_{0} l}{6 m\left(g-2 l \Omega^{2}\right)} \cos \Omega t+C_{2}^{\prime} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{g}{2 l}} t+\alpha_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Further, we obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
x= & \frac{1}{2} \xi - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \eta = \left[\frac{F_{0} l}{4 m(3 g-2 l \Omega^{2})} + \frac{F_{0} l}{4 m(g-2 l \Omega^{2})}\right] \cos \Omega t \\
& + C_{1} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{3g}{2l}} t+\alpha_{1}\right) + C_{2} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{g}{2l}} t+\alpha_{2}\right) \\
\theta= & -\frac{3}{2 l} \xi - \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2 l} \eta = \left[-\frac{3 F_{0}}{4 m(3g-2l\Omega^{2})} + \frac{F_{0}}{4m(g-2l\Omega^{2})}\right] \cos \Omega t 
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
-\frac{3}{l} C_{1} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{3g}{2l}} t+\alpha_{1}\right) + \frac{1}{l} C_{2} \cos \left(\sqrt{\frac{g}{2l}} t+\alpha_{2}\right)
$$
